response: Gravity is one of the four fundamental forces that govern the universe and is the weakest of the four. It is an attractive force that exists between all things, pulling them together. Gravity is described by the general theory of relativity proposed by Albert Einstein. Earth's gravity is the force that gives weight to physical objects and causes them to fall when dropped. This force also keeps the planets in orbit around the sun and the moon in orbit around Earth. The strength of gravity depends on the mass of the objects involved; the larger an object's mass, the stronger its gravitational pull. Gravity also operates over a distance; the farther away two objects are, the weaker the gravitational attraction between them. Understanding gravity helps us understand the formation of galaxies, stars, and planets and enables us to explore space.
